evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_baseline_t1_early scope.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: There is no evidence in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t1_early scope that contradicts the occurrence of communication/coordination breakdown among crew.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t1_early data, such as timing and crew interactions.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_baseline_t1_early scope.

defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination without breakdown
If procedural deviations better explained the events without coordination failure

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H5 directly describe communication and coordination actions and breakdowns among crew during the pushback, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown in the specified scope. The discriminator favors R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN over R1_PUSHBACK_PROCEDURAL_DEVIATION based on crew interaction details.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing procedural deviation from coordination failure

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t1_early data, such as timing and crew interactions.

assumptions: Crew interactions described reflect coordination dynamics relevant to the baseline data
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication without coordination issues
If timing or crew interactions differed significantly from baseline data
